list_page_teaser: The spiritual portraits of Lucy and her husband Ricky show why they so frequently disagree.  Click to learn more!
description_html:
This gallery contains images of the Ricardos and the Mertzes, characters on the show I Love Lucy, which aired from 1951-1957.

The show was the most-watched television program for four of its six seasons, ranking third in its first year and second in 1956-57. It was one of earliest successful situation comedies on television and people continue to enjoy the show today.

image_list.title: Lucy Ricardo
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Lucy's spiritual portrait shows she is very emotional, and is down-to-earth but gets plenty of ideas.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Lucy's dominant personality trait, her passion, warmth, and strongly emotional personality.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  Lucy's preference is very strong and in the show she is constantly riding an emotional rollercoaster, with Ricky, the Mertzes, and the entire audience riding along.
image_list.explain_aux: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Lucy's auxiliary personality trait, her realistic outlook and desire for new experiences.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  In this case, Lucy's preference is fairly mild and she is constantly coming up with new ideas for ways she can get new experiences, especially new ways of getting into show business or meeting famous people.

image_list.title: Ricky Ricardo
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Ricky's spiritual portrait shows he is realistic and very logical.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Ricky's dominant personality trait, his moderate preference for being more logical than emotional.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  Ricky's reasonableness is not as strong as Lucy's tendencies to be emotional, so although he tries to stay cool, Lucy's scheming usually pushes him eventually into anger or laughter -- and usually both.
image_list.explain_aux: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Ricky's auxiliary personality trait, his realistic outlook.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  In this case, Ricky's preference is stronger than Lucy's, and he demonstrates it by insisting she work at home and not pursue a career -- an attitude very realistic in the 1950s but not very realistic these days, over fifty years later.

image_list.title: Ethel Mertz
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Ethel's spiritual portrait shows she is also very emotional, but more easy-going and not as ambitious as Lucy.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Ethel's dominant personality trait, her realistic outlook and openness to new experiences.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  Ethel's preference is quite strong and she demonstrates it when she chooses to join and even help Lucy in her schemes rather than stay out of it and mind her own business.
image_list.explain_aux: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Ethel's auxiliary personality trait, her friendliness and warmth.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  Ethel's preference is very strong and she demonstrates it by the way she usually sides with the emotional Lucy when she has a difference of opinion with Ricky, who tends to be more logical.

image_list.title: Fred Mertz
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Fred's spiritual portrait shows he is very realistic and logical, showing emotion rarely if ever.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Fred's dominant personality trait, his realistic outlook.  In Introverts, the dominant trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long horizontal line to represent this.  Fred's preference is very strong and he demonstrates this trait in the way he is always looking for ways to save money.
image_list.explain_aux: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Fred's auxiliary personality trait, his objectivity.  In Introverts, the auxiliary trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a vertical line to represent this, because it is more evident than the dominant function.  Fred's preference is very strong and he demonstrates this tendency in the way he rarely displays any emotion.
